div1.p: No. 32, Consular Series. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, July 25, 1899.
Owen L. W. Smith, To Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. The necessity for a Well, on the Legation premises.
No. 32, Consular Series. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia; July 25, 1899.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to say, that having experienced the difficulties, struggles and hardships of the last dry season here, without having a well, on the Legation, premises; in trying to obtain water from private wells, on other lots; and having some knoweldged of the bad effects and dangers in the use of impure and muddy water, I have requested of the Hon. R. H. Joskson the administrator of the estate of which the Legation premises, fforms a part, to sink a well on the premises between this

this and the next dry season. He informs me, through his agent, Judge H. W. Travis, that if he sinks a well on the premises he will charge $350.00 per annum for rent, instead of $300.00 as now paid. The first years' rent contract will expire September 30, 1899. I would like to be advised before renewing. I will add, however, that as the location of the Legation in some what rocky, it is not certain that we can succeed in sinking a well, short of much blasting. In case we can it will hardly cost over fifty dollars; I would therefore, suggest the propriety of the Government authorizing me to have the well sunk, at a cost, not exceeding fifty dollars; as being much cheaper than having
having the administrator to have it done at an annual cost of fifty dollars, in additional rent.
Awaiting your advice and reply. I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith M. R. and C. General.
